01.png

DNA replication is a fundamental property of living organisms.Prior to cell division( fission in prokaryotes; mitosis and meiosis in eukaryotes), DNA must be replicated so that, after cell division, the resulting daughter cells each end uo with the same amount of genetic material as the original cell. In other words, DNA replication ensures the constancy and equality of distribution of genetic material in reproduction.
So far, we have learned the following: The DNA molecule is a double helix. Each of the two interwined strans is made up of many basic units called nucleotides. A nucleotide is coposed of 5-carbon sugar( deoxyribose), a phosphate group attached to the deoxyribose, and a nitrogenous base attached to the 1'C of the sugar. At the opposite end of the phosphate group is an OH group attached to the 3'C of the sugar. Therefore, each strand of DNA has two ends: the 5'P end and the 3'OH end. Here the two strands are dark orange and light orange in color, respectively.

Each original single stranded DNA serves as a template for synthesizing a new complmentary strand( dark blue and light blue).
This is called semiconservative method of DNA replication.
DNA replication is a complicated process.
Some key steps will be shown in the following pages.

In the first step of DNA replication, the enzyme helicase breaks the hydrogen bonds between the complementary bases of the double helix, turning double-stranded DNA into single-stranded DNA.
* Drag the helicase to the bottom of the double helix between the 2 strands.

The junction between the double stranded and the single stranded DNA is called replication fork.
After the double helix starts to unwind, proteins called single strand binding proteins, or SSBs, attached to the single strands to prevent them from coming back together.
* Drag one SSB to the 3' end of one single strand, and drag the SSB to the 5' end of the other single strand.

As you have seen, many SSBs are bound to the newly separated DNA strands to prevent them from forming double helix again.
Next, the RNA promise attaches to the unwound DNA strand. It is an enzyme that generates a short stretch of RNA primer that is complementary to DNA to initiate DNA synthesis.
* Drag one RNA primes molecule to the 3' end of one DNA strand so that it can travel in the 3' to 5' direction and ass nucleotides in the 5' to 3' direction. Silimarly, drag another RNA promise to the middle of the other single DNA strand.

After the RNA primers are generated, the RNA primes leaves the DNA strand, and the enzyme DNA polymerase attaches to the RNA primers, to synthesize a new complementary DNA strand in the 5' to 3' direction.

Note that, on the left side, the DNA polymerase moves on the template strand( deep red) is the 3' to 5' direction, and, at the same time, it synthesizes a new DNA strand in the 5' to 3' direction. The continuously synthesized new strand is called the leading strand ( dark blue).
On the other strand( right), however, the DNA polymerase travels away from the relocation fork so that more single stranded DNA becomes available for synthesizing a new DNA fragment. This strand is known as the lagging strand( light blue).
In order for more DNA to be synthesized on the lagging strand template, another RNA primer has to be generated by RNA primes.

Conclusions

DNA replication occurs prior to cell division so that there is no loss of DNA; the resulting daughter cells end up with the same amount of DNA as the original cell.
DNA replication in all known cells occurs semiconservatively.
Each of the original strands of DNA serves as a template for synthesizing a new DNA strand.
The leading strand is synthesized continuously, while the lagging strand is synthesized discontinuously.
Before the discontinuous stretches of newly synthesized DNA are joined together, they are known as Okazaki fragment.
DNA synthesis requires a preexisting primer, which is synthesized by the enzyme RNA primes.
Conclusions

The key enzymes in DNA replication are: 1) helices, which unwinds the double stranded DNA, 2) RNA primes, which synthesizes RNA primers, 3) DNA polymerase, which synthesizes DNA, 4) RNase H, which removes all of the nucleotides of the RNA primers except the last one, 5) DNA exonuclease, which removes the last RNA nucleotide( the RNA primer is replaced with a segment of newly synthesized DNA by another type of DNA polymerase( repairing enzyme), and 6) DNA ligase, which seals the nick between the Okazaki fragments through the formation of phosphodiester bonds.
